pull.title: test: tool wallet test coverage for unexpected writes to wallet
pull.body:
This pull request adds test coverage in `test/functional/tool_wallet.py` to reproduce unexpected writes to the wallet as described in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/15608 and serve as a benchmark for fixing the issue:

- Wallet tool `info` unexpectedly writes to the wallet file if the wallet file permissions are read/write.

- Wallet tool `info` raises with "Error loading . Is wallet being used by another process?" if the wallet file permissions are read-only.

Goals:

1. Reproduce the reported issue, define the current unexpected behavior, and add test coverage to guide a future fix. Add debug-level logging for sanity checking and commented-out assertions to be uncommented when fixing the issue. Add the same coverage to the wallet tool create test and the getwalletinfo test as regression tests while fixing the issue.

2. Add info log messages as there are currently none in the test file.

3. Split the tests out to separate functions as per review feedback.

Thanks to Marco Falke for pointing me in the right direction.

events.body:
<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->

The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers.

<!--174a7506f384e20aa4161008e828411d-->
### Conflicts
No conflicts as of last run.

Lowered the buffer size for the shasum function to 16Kb and hoisted that value to a constant. Rebased.

This should be ready for review.
Linter is complaining about unused code because it is in the commented-out tests and Appveyor seems to keep file perms at 666. Reworking.
Thanks for the review @laanwj and @MarcoFalke. I've pushed rebased commits that address your feedback. Are you able to rereview/retest?

verification.payload:
tree e96a6d598cd405f4983d1f02c42588d75a7cd887
parent 3bf2b3a37bbd550491d124b77fd7c1b2a7969f66
author Jon Atack <jon@atack.com> 1554306889 +0200
committer Jon Atack <jon@atack.com> 1562583748 +0200

test: Tool wallet test coverage for unexpected writes to wallet

This commit adds test coverage in `test/functional/tool_wallet.py` to reproduce unexpected writes to the wallet as described in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/15608:

    - wallet tool `info` unexpectedly writes to the wallet file if the wallet file permissions are read/write.

    - wallet tool `info` raises with "Error loading . Is wallet being used by another process?" if the wallet file permissions are read-only.

1. Reproduce the reported issue, define the current unexpected behavior, and add test coverage to guide a future fix in the form of commented-out assertions to be uncommented when testing/fixing.

2. Provisionally extend the same coverage to the wallet tool create test and the getwalletinfo test as regression tests while fixing the issue.

3. Add some logging for sanity checking.

------

Changes after rebase:

5. Make wallet_path an instance method instead of a function in tool_wallet.py as per Marco Falke review suggestion.

6. Assert wallet permissions instead of logging them in tool_wallet.py. This ran into an issue with Appveyor keeping permissions at 666 so allowed for 666 as a workaround.

7. Change the added logging from info to debug level.

8. More helpful assertions order in tool_wallet.py#assert_tool_output. This change makes #assert_tool_output raise "Error loading wallet.dat. Is wallet being used by another process?" rather than a less-helpful message when debugging the read-only wallet permissions issue.

events.message:
test: Tool wallet test coverage for unexpected writes to wallet

This commit adds test coverage in `test/functional/tool_wallet.py` to reproduce unexpected writes to the wallet as described in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/15608:

    - wallet tool `info` unexpectedly writes to the wallet file if the wallet file permissions are read/write.

    - wallet tool `info` raises with "Error loading . Is wallet being used by another process?" if the wallet file permissions are read-only.

1. Reproduce the reported issue, define the current unexpected behavior, and add test coverage to guide a future fix in the form of commented-out assertions to be uncommented when testing/fixing.

2. Provisionally extend the same coverage to the wallet tool create test and the getwalletinfo test as regression tests while fixing the issue.

3. Add some logging for sanity checking.

------

Changes after rebase:

5. Make wallet_path an instance method instead of a function in tool_wallet.py as per Marco Falke review suggestion.

6. Assert wallet permissions instead of logging them in tool_wallet.py. This ran into an issue with Appveyor keeping permissions at 666 so allowed for 666 as a workaround.

7. Change the added logging from info to debug level.

8. More helpful assertions order in tool_wallet.py#assert_tool_output. This change makes #assert_tool_output raise "Error loading wallet.dat. Is wallet being used by another process?" rather than a less-helpful message when debugging the read-only wallet permissions issue.

events.body: The lone Travis failure appears to be an unrelated `wait_until` timeout > 60 sec in `feature_block.py`.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -36,8 +39,29 @@ def assert_tool_output(self, output, *args):
         assert_equal(stderr, '')
         assert_equal(stdout, output)
 
-    def run_test(self):
+    def wallet_path(self):
+        return os.path.join(self.nodes[0].datadir, "regtest", "wallets", "wallet.dat")
comments.body: Use single quotes here like the rest of the file.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -36,8 +39,29 @@ def assert_tool_output(self, output, *args):
         assert_equal(stderr, '')
         assert_equal(stdout, output)
 
-    def run_test(self):
+    def wallet_path(self):
+        return os.path.join(self.nodes[0].datadir, "regtest", "wallets", "wallet.dat")
+
+    def wallet_shasum(self):
+        h = hashlib.sha1()
+        ba = bytearray(128*1024)
+        mv = memoryview(ba)
+        with open(self.wallet_path(), 'rb', buffering=0) as f:
+            for n in iter(lambda : f.readinto(mv), 0):
+                h.update(mv[:n])
+        return h.hexdigest()
+
+    def wallet_timestamp(self, op):
+        timestamp = os.path.getmtime(self.wallet_path())
+        self.log.info('Wallet file timestamp {0}: {1}'.format(op, timestamp))
+        return timestamp
 
+    def log_wallet_timestamp_comparison(self, new, old):
+        result = 'unchanged' if new == old else 'increased! **FIX ME**'
+        self.log.info('Wallet file timestamp {0}\n'.format(result))
comments.body: nit: instead of logging the timestamps and whether they changed, you might use `assert_equal` (or explicitly comment it out, if it currently fails)

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -46,9 +70,23 @@ def run_test(self):
         self.assert_raises_tool_error('Error loading wallet.dat. Is wallet being used by other process?', '-wallet=wallet.dat', 'info')
         self.assert_raises_tool_error('Error: no wallet file at nonexistent.dat', '-wallet=nonexistent.dat', 'info')
 
-        # stop the node to close the wallet to call info command
+        # Stop the node to close the wallet to call the info command.
+        self.log.info('Stop node\n')
         self.stop_node(0)
 
+        # Wallet tool info should work with wallet file permissions set to read-only.
+        # This needs to be fixed.
+        self.log.info('Set wallet file permissions to read-only')
+        os.chmod(self.wallet_path(), 0o400)
+        self.log.info('Call wallet tool info')
+        self.assert_raises_tool_error('Error loading . Is wallet being used by another process?', 'info')
+        self.log.info('Wallet tool info command raises loading error! **FIX ME**')
comments.body: TODO's shouldn't be logged, but added as inline comments

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -36,8 +39,29 @@ def assert_tool_output(self, output, *args):
         assert_equal(stderr, '')
         assert_equal(stdout, output)
 
-    def run_test(self):
+    def wallet_path(self):
+        return os.path.join(self.nodes[0].datadir, "regtest", "wallets", "wallet.dat")
+
+    def wallet_shasum(self):
+        h = hashlib.sha1()
+        ba = bytearray(128*1024)
+        mv = memoryview(ba)
+        with open(self.wallet_path(), 'rb', buffering=0) as f:
+            for n in iter(lambda : f.readinto(mv), 0):
+                h.update(mv[:n])
+        return h.hexdigest()
+
+    def wallet_timestamp(self, op):
+        timestamp = os.path.getmtime(self.wallet_path())
+        self.log.info('Wallet file timestamp {0}: {1}'.format(op, timestamp))
+        return timestamp
 
+    def log_wallet_timestamp_comparison(self, new, old):
+        result = 'unchanged' if new == old else 'increased! **FIX ME**'
+        self.log.info('Wallet file timestamp {0}\n'.format(result))
comments.body: Thanks for reviewing! I added both logs and assertions with the logs serving as a sanity check for the assertions. Based on your feedback, I switched the assertions from passing ones that need to be inverted, to failing ones that need to be uncommented.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -46,9 +70,23 @@ def run_test(self):
         self.assert_raises_tool_error('Error loading wallet.dat. Is wallet being used by other process?', '-wallet=wallet.dat', 'info')
         self.assert_raises_tool_error('Error: no wallet file at nonexistent.dat', '-wallet=nonexistent.dat', 'info')
 
-        # stop the node to close the wallet to call info command
+        # Stop the node to close the wallet to call the info command.
+        self.log.info('Stop node\n')
         self.stop_node(0)
 
+        # Wallet tool info should work with wallet file permissions set to read-only.
+        # This needs to be fixed.
+        self.log.info('Set wallet file permissions to read-only')
+        os.chmod(self.wallet_path(), 0o400)
+        self.log.info('Call wallet tool info')
+        self.assert_raises_tool_error('Error loading . Is wallet being used by another process?', 'info')
+        self.log.info('Wallet tool info command raises loading error! **FIX ME**')
comments.body: Done. Waiting for Travis CI to pass locally and then will push a rebased update.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -87,15 +161,32 @@ def run_test(self):
             Address Book: 0
         ''')
         self.assert_tool_output(out, '-wallet=foo', 'create')
-
+        shasum_after = self.wallet_shasum()
comments.body: I understand surrounding the `info` methods, but what is the logic here? creating a wallet that already exists should leave it untouched?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -36,8 +42,32 @@ def assert_tool_output(self, output, *args):
         assert_equal(stderr, '')
         assert_equal(stdout, output)
 
-    def run_test(self):
+    def wallet_path(self):
+        return os.path.join(self.nodes[0].datadir, 'regtest', 'wallets', 'wallet.dat')
comments.body:
style-nit: Could be a "const" member, set in the first line of `run_test`?

```py
self.wallet_path = os.path.join(...

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -36,8 +42,32 @@ def assert_tool_output(self, output, *args):
         assert_equal(stderr, '')
         assert_equal(stdout, output)
 
-    def run_test(self):
+    def wallet_path(self):
+        return os.path.join(self.nodes[0].datadir, 'regtest', 'wallets', 'wallet.dat')
+
+    def wallet_shasum(self):
+        h = hashlib.sha1()
+        mv = memoryview(bytearray(BUFFER_SIZE))
+        with open(self.wallet_path(), 'rb', buffering=0) as f:
+            for n in iter(lambda : f.readinto(mv), 0):
+                h.update(mv[:n])
+        return h.hexdigest()
+
+    def wallet_timestamp(self, op):
+        timestamp = os.path.getmtime(self.wallet_path())
+        self.log.info('Wallet file timestamp {0}: {1}'.format(op, timestamp))
comments.body: style-nit: Is it required to log the timestamp in a simple getter method? I'd prefer if it was logged by the caller or just asserted (Looks like you already do both of that)

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -36,8 +42,32 @@ def assert_tool_output(self, output, *args):
         assert_equal(stderr, '')
         assert_equal(stdout, output)
 
-    def run_test(self):
+    def wallet_path(self):
+        return os.path.join(self.nodes[0].datadir, 'regtest', 'wallets', 'wallet.dat')
+
+    def wallet_shasum(self):
+        h = hashlib.sha1()
+        mv = memoryview(bytearray(BUFFER_SIZE))
+        with open(self.wallet_path(), 'rb', buffering=0) as f:
+            for n in iter(lambda : f.readinto(mv), 0):
+                h.update(mv[:n])
+        return h.hexdigest()
+
+    def wallet_timestamp(self, op):
+        timestamp = os.path.getmtime(self.wallet_path())
+        self.log.info('Wallet file timestamp {0}: {1}'.format(op, timestamp))
+        return timestamp
 
+    def log_wallet_permissions(self):
+        result = oct(os.lstat(self.wallet_path()).st_mode)[-3:]
+        self.log.info('Verifying wallet file permissions: {}'.format(result))
comments.body: You aren't verifying anything here, it seems. I'd prefer if this was just a simple getter util method and the caller logs/asserts if appropriate.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -36,8 +42,32 @@ def assert_tool_output(self, output, *args):
         assert_equal(stderr, '')
         assert_equal(stdout, output)
 
-    def run_test(self):
+    def wallet_path(self):
+        return os.path.join(self.nodes[0].datadir, 'regtest', 'wallets', 'wallet.dat')
+
+    def wallet_shasum(self):
+        h = hashlib.sha1()
+        mv = memoryview(bytearray(BUFFER_SIZE))
+        with open(self.wallet_path(), 'rb', buffering=0) as f:
+            for n in iter(lambda : f.readinto(mv), 0):
+                h.update(mv[:n])
+        return h.hexdigest()
+
+    def wallet_timestamp(self, op):
+        timestamp = os.path.getmtime(self.wallet_path())
+        self.log.info('Wallet file timestamp {0}: {1}'.format(op, timestamp))
+        return timestamp
 
+    def log_wallet_permissions(self):
+        result = oct(os.lstat(self.wallet_path()).st_mode)[-3:]
+        self.log.info('Verifying wallet file permissions: {}'.format(result))
+
+    def log_wallet_timestamp_comparison(self, old, new):
+        result = 'unchanged' if new == old else 'increased!'
+        self.log.info('Wallet file timestamp {}\n'.format(result))
comments.body: This looks like a test-dev debug statement. Maybe use `self.log.debug`?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -59,12 +101,32 @@ def run_test(self):
             Address Book: 3
         ''')
         self.assert_tool_output(out, '-wallet=wallet.dat', 'info')
-
-        # mutate the wallet to check the info command output changes accordingly
+        shasum_after = self.wallet_shasum()
+        timestamp_after = self.wallet_timestamp(' after info')
+        self.log.info('Setting wallet file permissions to read/write')
+        os.chmod(self.wallet_path(), stat.S_IRUSR | stat.S_IWUSR) # Set wallet permissions to 600
+        self.log_wallet_permissions()
+        assert_equal(shasum_before, shasum_after)
+        self.log.info('Wallet file shasum unchanged')
+        self.log_wallet_timestamp_comparison(timestamp_before, timestamp_after)
+        #
+        # TODO: Wallet tool info should not write to the wallet file.
+        # This assertion should be uncommented and succeed:
+        # assert_equal(timestamp_before, timestamp_after)
+
+        # Mutate the wallet to verify that the info command output changes accordingly.
+        self.log.info('Starting node')
         self.start_node(0)
+
+        self.log.info('Generating transaction to mutate wallet')
         self.nodes[0].generate(1)
+
+        self.log.info('Stopping node\n')
         self.stop_node(0)
 
+        self.log.info('Calling wallet tool info after generating a transaction')
+        shasum_before = self.wallet_shasum()
comments.body:
Looks like you are overwriting a previous symbol with the same name. I think it is clearer to split the tests into smaller ones, so that overwriting does not happen. I.e.

```py
  self run_test(self):
   self.run_test_foo_bar()
   self.run_test_gen_tx()

  def run_test_foo_bar(self):
    assert True

...

+        self.log.info('Wallet file timestamp {}\n'.format(result))
comments.body: Done, switched to loglevel `debug` for all the timestamp and shasum logging.

comments.body: Yes, updated test name and logging to clarify that a bit. Happy to remove if you reckon it isn't a useful safeguard while fixing the issue.
